CAPTION FIG1.png: 'Figure 1: 1/LWEQ module sequence alignment. Alignment of the conserved \\(\\mathcal{C}\\)-terminal domain common to mouse (_Mn_) and \\(\\mathcal{C}\\). _elegans_ (_Cc_) in _italin_, the _Dictyaselium_ (_Dd_) talin homolog filopodia, the putative _C. elegans_ Sla2 homolog, and _S. cerevisiae_ (_Sc_) Sla2. The four conserved blocks, originally identified using the block maker program (34), are boxed; identities between all five sequences are highlighted by shading in the column, conservative substitutions are indicated by \\(+\\). The most conserved positions (at least four out of five residues identical) are marked by a solid circle above the column. Block 1 contains 17% identities and 48% similaries; the values for blocks 2–4 are 63%/80%, 57%/83%, and 46%/66%, respectively.\n\n'
CAPTION FIG2.png: 'Figure 2: F-actin coedimentation vertebrate actin. (\\(\\mathcal{A}\\)) SDS/PAGE Rabbit skeletal muscle actin (0-30 \\(\\mu\\)M) was mixed with either native mouse tailin (25 \\(\\mu\\)M), GST-Tn (2.0 \\(\\mu\\)M), GST-Sla2 (2.0 \\(\\mu\\)M), or GST (2.0 \\(\\mu\\)M), and F-actin coedimentation analyzed. All of the supernatant panels and the tailin and GST pellet panels were visualized with Coomassie blue; the fission protein pellet fractions were detected by immunoblotting (see text). (\\(B\\)) Quantitative analysis. Supernatant depletion, as a measure of cosedimentation, of tailin (\\(\\mathcal{C}\\)), GST-Tn (\\(\\bullet\\)), GST-Sla2 (\\(\\mathcal{V}\\)), and GST (\\(\\blacktriangledown\\)) was determined densitometrically using the gels shown in \\(\\mathcal{A}\\). (\\(C\\)) Quantitative analysis: GST-Sla2 mutant. Supernatant depletion was performed as in \\(\\mathcal{A}\\) on GST-Sla2 (\\(\\mathcal{C}\\)), the mutant GST-Sla2R95Sc(\\(\\mathcal{V}\\)), and GST (\\(\\bullet\\)). The shift in electrophoretic mobility of the Sla2 mutant is shown (_Israel_).\n\n'
CAPTION FIG3.png: 'Figure 3: F-actin cosedimentation: yeast actin. Cosedimentation of talin (○), GST-Tn (○), GST-Sha2 (■), and GST (**v**) with yeast F-actin was measured as described in Fig. 2 except for the following changes in protein concentrations: yeast actin (0–10 μM); talin, GST-Tn, GST-Sha2, and GST (2.0 μM each).\n\n'
CAPTION FIG4.png: 'Figure 4: Competition of GST-Tn 245–2541 for talin F-actin banding activity. Rabbit actin (10 \\(\\mu\\)M) and talin (1 \\(\\mu\\)M) were mixed in the presence of increasing amounts of GST-Tn (0–30 \\(\\mu\\)M), and actin polymerization, centrifugation, SDS/PAGE, and densitometry were performed as previously described (Fig 2). Values reported are averages of three separate experiments. GST (0–20 \\(\\mu\\)M) had no effect on talin binding to F-actin (not shown).\n\n'
CAPTION FIG5.png: 'Figure 5: F-actin bundling. Actin (3 \\(\\mu\\)M) was polymerized in the presence of (\\(A\\)) talin, (\\(B\\)) GST, (\\(C\\)) GST-Tn, or (\\(D\\)) GST-Sla2 (3 \\(\\mu\\)M each), and the resulting F-actin preparations were negatively stained with uranyl formate and visualized by electron microscopy. (Bar = 10 \\(\\mu\\)M).\n\n'
CAPTION FIG6.png: 'Figure 6: Nucleation of F-actin polymerization. Actin (6 \\(\\mu\\)M, 54%) pyrene-labeled) was polymerized alone (○) or in the presence of tail (2 \\(\\mu\\)M, \\(\\triangledown\\)), GST-Tn, GST-Sla2, or GST (2 \\(\\mu\\)M each (○), or gelsolin (3 nM, \\(\\blacktriangledown\\)) and polymerization was monitored by the increase in pyrene fluorescence.\n\n'
